author: Neeladri Bhattacharjee
title: AFC Asian Cup: Aymen Hussein double helps Iraq stun four-time winner Japan - Sportstar
text:
Football has a fickle memory. It thrives in the present and often, changes for a better future.
That was what Japan coach Hajime Moriyasu had suggested in the pre-match press conference before its clash against Iraq in the AFC Asian Cup 2023, at the Education City Stadium on Friday.
The last time Japan played Iraq in Qatar, a 2-2 draw at the Jassim bin Hamad Stadium in 1993 had broken dreams of playing its maiden FIFA World Cup. â€œMost of the players in the current squad were not even born when the match was played,â€ Moriyasu had said, â€œthat game is past now.â€
But ghastly memories of that three-decade-old match came back to haunt the Samurai Blue as Iraq rode on raucous fan support and clinical attacking to beat Japan 2-1 in its second group-stage game.
Both goals came off Aymen Husseinâ€™s head, who was subbed off at half-time in what looked like a problem in his right hamstring.
ALSO READ: South Korea keeper Kim ruled out of competition with knee injury
This was the first win since 1982 for the Central Asian side against the four-time Asian champion when it had beaten Japan 1-0 at the Asian Games.
Iraq created overloads in Japanâ€™s half right from kick-off, mirroring Japanâ€™s start against Vietnam in its first game. In that match, Moriyasuâ€™s side had opened the scoring within 11 minutes.
Iraq, under Jesus Garcia, drew first blood even quicker.
In the fifth minute, Ahmed Yahya Al-Hajjajâ€™s through ball was received by Ali Jasim Elaibi on the left flank, who put his foot on the gas to maraud along the left flank and deliver a cross.
Though Zion Suzuki, Japanâ€™s goalkeeper, pushed the ball out, it fell for Aymen Hussein, who headed the ball in causing an eruption of joy in the stadium.
The 38,663 fans at the stadium, most of whom were Iraqi, made the air crackle with Viking claps, regional songs and chants of â€œIraq!â€ and made sure a trailing Japan remained on the backfoot with whistles and boos every time it had the ball.
IRAQ ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¶ is in the #AsianCup2023 Round of 16 #HayyaAsia pic.twitter.com/Ia8f1sJKsb
â€” AFC Asian Cup Qatar 2023 (@Qatar2023en) January 19, 2024

Marketing mÃ³vil El mercado de videojuegos para mÃ³viles se ha convertido en uno de los sectores mÃ¡s dinÃ¡micos y lucrativos de la industria del entretenimiento, ya que de acuerdo a Statista, al menos el 57 por ciento de una campaÃ±a se va en pauto a telÃ©fonos mÃ³viles.
Con millones de usuarios activos diarios, las marcas que desarrollan y publicitan estos juegos han adoptado estrategias de marketing innovadoras para captar la atenciÃ³n de los jugadores y convertirlos en consumidores leales.
Una de las tÃ¡cticas mÃ¡s efectivas es el uso de publicidad en redes sociales, donde los anuncios interactivos y los videos cortos muestran las caracterÃ­sticas principales del juego.
Red Bull se convierte en principal patrocinador del AtlÃ©tico de Madrid Plataformas como TikTok, Instagram y YouTube son clave para atraer a audiencias jÃ³venes mediante contenido creativo y viral. AdemÃ¡s, las colaboraciones con influencers y streamers populares amplifican el alcance, ya que sus recomendaciones generan confianza entre sus seguidores.
Asimismo, las campaÃ±as de lanzamiento con recompensas, como eventos pre-registro, generan expectativa y motivan a los jugadores a descargar el juego antes de su estreno.
Pubg Mobile Un ejemplo reciente es el caso de Pubg Mobile, quien ha trabajado constantemente en poder hacer colaboraciones desde distintas plataformas para posicionarse como un juego de competencia en mÃ³viles, a lo que se puede encontrar con ejecuciones distintas y pautas en otros medios, algo Ãºnico frente a diferentes alternativas.
